Name: 1_genocide_intent_of genocide_genocide is
Representative_Docs: ['first of all nobody legitimate is claiming that what israel is doing is a genocide purely because of the death toll maybe some random redditor said that to you in the comments but your post makes it seem like that s a widely held belief listen buddy your experiences are not my experiences you re partially right informed people cite a broader range of reasons but even on reddit and other social media platforms the death toll is constantly used as the centerpiece of moral arguments and the simpletons in question here often blackmail you emotionally because of it stating something along the lines of k dead genocide and they shout this out far more often than references to international law legal thresholds of intent or definitions under the genocide convention that s the bs i was pointing out if sheer body count is your criteria then yes october th would also qualify under that logic even if the execution scale was smaller you can t claim the moral high ground by focusing on outcomes while ignoring intent in actuality the allegations of genocide are usually centered around israel s decision to agreed and i ll even acknowledge that those allegations deserve investigation and scrutiny but israel has stated its intent is to dismantle hamas which is a group that carried out a massacre and openly calls for israel s destruction now can a counterterror campaign go too far and violate humanitarian law of course can a disproportionate response lead to war crimes yes that s why those charges exist separately from genocide but to cross into genocide you must prove intent to destroy a population as such and intent is incredibly hard to prove which is why the bar is so high in international law israeli ministers have made appalling comments but they also exist in a country with a history of internal accountability even if imperfect for hamas that action was confined to a single day years ago so the timeline is your issue and you call my post awful tsk tsk yes it was one day in which over civilians were intentionally murdered women raped families burned alive and children kidnapped that s ideological extermination which also serves as grounds for genocide in intent even if not in scale you don t need to perform mental gymnastics to prove that because hamas s charter calls for the destruction of the jewish state and people they ve said it plainly and repeatedly the only reason october th didn t reach rwanda like numbers is because they were physically stopped the fact that they wanted to go further but couldn t is key you don t get to say well it was just one day when that day s goal was the obliteration of a population genocide has never been about killing as many people as possible in as fast a time as possible it s about destroying a population systematically in whole or in part through a variety of means particularly when trying to do it under international scrutiny yes and israel clearly has the capacity to do more harm than it has it s not something i m suggesting israel should boast about but it s something to note when intent is being questioned if israel truly intended to wipe out palestinians they have the means they haven t that fact alone isn t exoneration but it s relevant to the question of whether genocide is truly underway or whether we re witnessing a brutal counterterror operation against a terror group that embeds itself among civilians by your own example the germans in namibia created death camps however they didn t allow humanitarian corridors they didn t drop leaflets urging evacuation they didn t provide water power or aid after the fighting began israel has done all those things even if insufficiently again i m trying to get it through thick skulls it s not proof of moral purity but it questions intent this post was horrible i would recommend you delete it and try again if you didn t like it that s your opinion but just because you disagree doesn t mean it lacks value the post was simply meant to challenge oversimplified questions like if israel were really trying to defend itself why are so many palestinians dead that question gets asked daily and it deserves a hard uncomfortable answer i tried to provide one', 'the aspect that i take issue with is that the icj has specifically said that s not the case if you re inferring genocidal intent from a pattern of conduct which amnesty international is doing in their report ai cites icj s croatia v serbia judgment they even cite paragraph of it on page of their report paragraph of the icj s judgment states the court recalls that in the passage in question in its judgment it accepted the possibility of genocidal intent being established indirectly by inference the notion of reasonableness must necessarily be regarded as implicit in the reasoning of the court thus to state that for a pattern of conduct to be accepted as evidence of existence of genocidal intent it must be such that it could only point to the existence of such intent amounts to saying that in order to infer the existence of dolus specialis from a pattern of conduct it is necessary and sufficient that this is the only inference that could reasonably be drawn from the acts in question to interpret paragraph of the judgment in any other way would make it impossible to reach conclusions by way of inference if amnesty international is going to infer genocidal intent from the acts israel has done then it is necessary that genocide is the only inference that can be drawn from the acts if any other reasonable inference can be drawn from the acts then it s impossible to conclude genocidal intent from the actions for example a reasonable inference from the acts israel has done is that they re fighting a war and just don t care about palestinian lives and are committing other not genocide war crimes by targeting civilians if that s the case then genocidal intent cannot be established through inference and since genocidal intent is necessary to commit genocide you can not conclude israel is doing genocide amnesty international changes that to only reasonable inference that the state also has the intent to destroy the group in whole or in part if genocidal intent is to be inferred from a pattern of conduct then there is no also amnesty international doesn t care and infers genocidal intent even though genocide is not the only reasonable inference from israel s pattern of conduct essentially amnesty international thinks the icj s way of inferring genocidal intent is too narrow so they change it so they can say israel is committing genocide it s gross and wrong and is easy to see', 'does israel have a plan of complete extermination like the nazis did i don t think so you seem to believe that a genocide can only fit this description but in fact the legal definition is far broader than that no it s not far broader than that the legal definition requires a specific intent to biologically destroy a protected group in whole or in part so yes they do need to have a specific intent for complete extermination of the palestinians in gaza or a part that is substantial to their biological survival e g the entire male population if there s no intent to physically destroy a protected group there s simply no genocide beyond the legal considerations i used this term to qualify the very real destructive intent toward pakestinian identity and society the gov seeks to destroy all possibility of life in gaza to destroy institutions and the entire social fabric of course it wants to destroy institutions of an enemy that has a singular desire to eliminate them and a social fabric that s deeply embedded with said enemy the allies in ww destroyed german and japanese institutions entire social fabric in wars against their entire societies while killing hundreds of thousands of civilians and burning multiple cities to the ground they did not commit a genocide even the most gentle kinds of serious wars like the iraq war where the goal was not merely to not target the civilian population according to ihl rules but to make friends with them and be greeted as liberators by no means the default obvious or legally required case was still about destroying institutions and to some extent social fabric which was deeply embedded with baath arguing that destroying institutions makes a genocide doesn t just go beyond legal considerations it goes beyond any reasonable definition of genocide full stop as for destroying all possibility of life in gaza as i said the very existence of the ghf undermines this thesis not supports it but even if we just conclude that the goal here is to make gaza unlivable in order to expel the palestinians to somewhere else it means it s not genocidal intent the law is very clear on this the icty and icj ruled that actual close range massacres not merely bulldozing buildings are not genocide because they were aimed to expel rather than destroy to this day most israelis do not recognize the palestinian plight as a legitimate aspiration that s a pretty wild argument do you think any of israel s enemies throughout its entire history recognized the plight of the jewish people and their legitimate aspirations to a state or for that matter their even more legitimate aspiration to not have their existing state eliminated and its jewish population subjugated expelled or exterminated the actual palestinian aspiration and the root cause of the palestinian plight does that mean that every war israel has fought not just oct th and not just against the palestinians was actually a genocide against the israeli jews when snipers systematically shoot children in the head this goes beyond simple war crimes it s not clear it s even war crimes at all let alone it being systematic a word that doesn t just mean happened multiple times or even committed by idf soldiers to begin with but let s assume for a moment that the idf high command ordered snipers to shoot dozens of innocent palestinian children in the head that would be a war crime and a crime against humanity of murder it would not even be the crime of extermination let alone genocide genocide doesn t mean war crimes that are exceptionally cruel anymore than it means wars that disrupt institutions and social structures again if israel actually had genocidal intent it would not be risking its soldiers lives to snipe at a few dozen random palestinian children or to use live fire for crowd control it would be carrying out the kinds of mass close range executions we ve seen in all the actual genocides including oct th we would at least see the israelis actually doing what they were accused for months of doing and firebombing the mawasi refugee area or simply starving all the gazans to death israel had the means and the opportunity to destroy the gazans for over a year and a half the fact it didn t do it shows it simply doesn t have the intent']

Name: 2_genocide_of genocide_genocide is_group
Representation: ['genocide', 'of genocide', 'genocide is', 'group', 'the group', 'intent', 'not genocide', 'it genocide', 'definition', 'genocide and']
Representative_Docs: ['you can look this up for yourself if you d like to confirm this but the definition of genocide is generally accepted to contain the following elements any of the following acts committed with intent to destroy in whole or in part a national ethnical racial or religious group as such killing members of the group causing serious bodily or mental harm to members of the group deliberately inflicting on the group conditions of life calculated to bring about its physical destruction in whole or in part imposing measures intended to prevent births within the group forcibly transferring children of the group to another group is it something on par with rwanda or pol pot in terms of scale no but if we were to exclude the obvious ones of deaths and injuries i d say the years long blockade preventing imports exports destruction of thousands of homes and increase in the number of illegal settlements by displacement would fit the criteria for the nd and rd elements', 'genocide doesn t mean it has to wipe out the victim popular or decrease even from us holocaust memorial genocide is an internationally recognized crime where acts are committed with the intent to destroy in whole or in part a national ethnic racial or religious group these acts fall into five categories killing members of the group causing serious bodily or mental harm to members of the group deliberately inflicting on the group conditions of life calculated to bring about its physical destruction in whole or in part imposing measures intended to prevent births within the group forcibly transferring children of the group to another group', 'genocide is genocide']

Name: 5_apartheid_an apartheid_apartheid state_south
Representative_Docs: ['let me start off by agreeing that any person who is pro one side is less educated if you are pro one side you definitely didnt take the time to internalize how complex the parents outcries are usually enough to make an arab teacher not the right fit at this point in time so sad so sad additionally up until all arab teachers has to be vetted by the general security Name: 6_food_aid_famine_starvation
Representative_Docs: ['ok i ll let the article speak for itself the flour and rice come from donations gathered by the un and international humanitarian groups who usually buy the food in the west bank jordan or abroad and transport it through israel to gaza according to humanitarian sources the idf does not allow the supplies to be properly secured before trucks leave kerem shalom to enter the areas where starving gazans live sources in gaza report that idf soldiers rush aid workers to load cargo quickly then trucks are often delayed for hours and forced to take dangerous routes because the food isn t securely tied down it s easy to steal and most of the aid entering gaza is looted on the way some food also spills due to severe road damage for months the un and humanitarian aid groups have pleaded with the idf to allow food to enter through other crossings to give them time to secure and protect shipments and to use safer routes to ensure aid reaches those in need their requests have been repeatedly denied this is just one of many obstacles that israel places in the way of feeding gaza s residents and stopping the hunger crisis on the surface there is a puzzling gap between israel s repeated claims of increasing food supplies to gaza and the ongoing daily reports of deaths from starvation and severe malnutrition especially among children obstacles imposed by israel diaspora affairs minister amichai chikli has blocked dozens of organizations attempting to deliver aid police have failed to provide the necessary escort for trucks crossing from the jordanian border the idf delays trucks at the kerem shalom crossing and limits loading times which impacts drivers ability to secure the cargo the kerem shalom crossing is closed on fridays and saturdays aid workers and international volunteers are not permitted to enter gaza through kerem shalom at the same time as the trucks the idf has established checkpoints within gaza that impede the movement of trucks gaza s social order is rapidly deteriorating because many police officers have been targeted by the idf unrwa s activities are being disrupted restrictions persist on the entry of certain medical supplies and foods the reason is that humanitarian organizations and un agencies including the world food program unicef the world health organization and dozens more have been unable to rebuild the food distribution network that operated in gaza before the current crisis began on march at that time israel closed the border crossings for days entirely causing the network to collapse', 'your post is dripping with sarcasm and outrage at this moment there are current global conflicts with more casualties and more displaced than the israel gaza war but fine you ve chosen this one as your hill to die on so the problem is that hamas has stolen the food and aid that has gone in to gaza previously stolen from the civilian population stolen food and medicine from starving children that need it this has made it challenging to get food to the people that need it you may or may not know that the palestinian peace advocate ahmed fouad alkhatib recommended parachuting aid in because it was harder to intercept which israel and other countries were doing i don t blame you for being concerned when i googled whether people were starving here were the headlines nbc starvation looms as israel s total blockade on gaza enters its third month starvation is not happening but it looms al jaz updates israel kills world complicit in starvation of gaza children note no mention if the were all hamas part hamas and the implicit call for nations to do something and of course the mention of children again current conflicts in the world in similar or worse situation un news gaza worst case scenario unfolds as brutal aid blockade threatens mass starvation note it is not here yet but threatening un news gazans face hunger crisis as aid blockade nears two months bbc news gaza mass starvation warning the strangest thing is that israel is expected to deliver food to its enemy as if england delivered food to the germans in ww in any event there is a story days ago about idf planning major shift in gaza aid delivery in bid to thwart hamas diversion the plan is that international organizations and private security contractors will hand out boxes of food to individual gazan families the whole sale distribution of food wasn t working because it was all being stolen by the criminally unethical hamas and its palestinian supporters in the new plan each family will have a designated representative tasked with reaching a security zone in southern gaza where aid will be distributed each box will have enough food to last several days then the family representatives return to the security zone to receive the next parcel israel believes this method will make it harder for hamas to divert aid to its fighters interestingly now qatar and egypt are supporting an initiative calling for days of calm that would see the release of the remaining israeli captives in exchange for allowing food and shelter i m hopeful and i hope you are as well that hamas will accept this qatar egypt plan they have been prolonging a lot of suffering so people like you can blame israel for all of it according to the deal they would have to release the hostages which would mark a turning point and probably the beginning of the end of the war', 'on the common argument that israel is using starvation as a means of committing genocide while there have been periods where israel has restricted the amount of aid entering gaza they have still facilitated over million tons of aid since the start of the war the reason aid flows have varied significantly is due to israel being influenced by ceasefire negotiations various military operations shifting border policies and logistical constraints currently the only part of gaza where famine has been declared is in gaza city a km stretch of land note that the gaza strip is km in its entirety in northern gaza that is outside of the designated humanitarian zones where it remains a major combat zone due to hamas still retaining control over significant areas especially civilian populated neighborhoods israel has just launched operation gideon s chariots ii four days ago to advance into this area a famine is classified using the integrated food security phase classification ipc when at least of households face extreme food insecurity acute malnutrition in children exceeds and the death rate surpasses two people per per day due to starvation or related causes with gaza s population of over million this would mean at least dead each day for it to be classed as a famine in the whole strip in almost years of fighting the estimated number of dead due to starvation is currently just over half the number required per day to declare a famine for a famine to be declared by the ipc in gaza city independent media investigations show that the ipc lowered the malnutrition threshold from to and shifted its measurement method from the standard weight and height indicators to the less precise mid upper arm circumference muac metric as mentioned in the footnotes of the report they also withdrew the death toll requirement mentioned above the reason this was done was due to an assumption that the number of those dead from starvation is vastly higher than reported however recent scientific studies done on this that take into account non violent deaths alongside the gaza ministry of health s reliability while using the same capture recapture method used by others such as in the often quoted lancet study do not reflect this as the vast majority of estimated deaths as of june according to the publication referenced prior are from violence as opposed to starvation dehydration or disease so just to summarise israel has in fact facilitated large amounts of aid into gaza where israel retains some level of control famine has not been declared famine has only been declared in a localised area where israel lacks control and where hamas still retains de facto governance and control the ipc changed the metrics in order to declare famine in this localised area this declaration is now being used to claim that there is famine in gaza to apply political pressure on israel while playing into the narrative that all of gaza is starving by means of misleading language therefore the presence of famine can be explained as a distribution problem due to hamas s continued actions and refusal to surrender whereby they are intentionally misappropriating humanitarian aid while allowing the people who they still hold control over to starve in order to apply political pressure aka lawfare on israel meanwhile international organisations such as the ipc have been influenced by politicisation through which they have applied an eased methodology with little transparency of doing so edit comments and days later yet not a single person has challenged anything i wrote just insults being thrown with practically every rule broken multiple times let me make some things clear to those who think i am justifying or denying that there is starvation nothing in my post suggests this to those who think i am in approval of israel s conduct nothing in my post suggests this to those who think that i am saying that the amount of aid entering gaza is sufficient nothing in my post suggests this my post is about the declaration of famine and genocide nothing else never believe that anti semites are completely unaware of the absurdity of their replies they know that their remarks are frivolous open to challenge but they are amusing themselves for it is their adversary who is obliged to use words responsibly since he believes in words the anti semites have the right to play they even like to play with discourse for by giving ridiculous reasons they discredit the seriousness of their interlocutors they delight in acting in bad faith since they seek not to persuade by sound argument but to intimidate and disconcert if you press them too closely they will abruptly fall silent loftily indicating by some phrase that the time for argument is past jean paul sartre if anyone would like to debate me specifically about whether israel s overall intent is genocide feel free to check out my other post i am always up for a discussion or debate']

Name: 7_netanyahu_he_netanyahu is_his
Representative_Docs: ['what is it you think netanyahu has said', 'edit since i guess a lot of people here clearly noticed the news outside of israel isn t broadcasting it or if they are it s incorrectly because media these days is usually only for against israel claims or maybe international news outlet can t obtain verify and publish the information as quickly as local news it is now occupying a large estate of the front page in cnn and bbc and also on the front page of le monde the straits time and news just to name a few others in various region look this might not be the post for it and i understand that emotion is running high but if you default to blaming everything under the sun to be against israel prepare to be called out i ve always said that my sympathies lies with the innocents on both side of the conflict my thoughts go to their family and i condemn their execution i do however think that this was avoidable i won t go as far as say that netanyahu don t care at all about the hostages although sometime i wonder giving him the benefit of doubt i think he just doesn t care enough about them to negotiate with the hamas that is to say if the idf is successful at rescuing the hostages then great but he d rather pursue his goal of total victory over the hamas whatever that means than to have a ceasefire now and get the hostages back via non military means now i get that such decisions can be justified don t negotiate with terrorists or you ll encourage them if hamas is left alive more israeli will die in the future but the reality is that hostage rescue is difficult and failure would very likely lead to the loss of the hostage s life i support an immediate ceasefire ideally permanent but even the hamas dropped that requirement at least until haniyeh got killed with a return of the hostages frankly speaking i don t see the hamas being able to pull off anything that the idf couldn t stop as long as they keep their eyes on the ball so there is no need to waste time which the hostages don t have on a total victory i don t know what the average israeli want i know there are people protesting against the government but i do not know if they represent a majority but i am pretty sure netanyahu has decided that worst come to worst he is willing to lose any hostages that can t be militarily rescued', 'no one says israel netanyahu funded hamas directly but rather that they allowed qatari money to flow into gaza to the hands of hamas since hamas has been the governing force in gaza it runs social programs and police and the government structure schools and hospitals are funded largely by the un and donors thus the money that hamas received can be thought of as money that is meant for welfare development governance etc in gaza israel and specifically netanyahu would say something like we want them to be able to have some basic living standards and we want it to go through us so that they have some incentive to play ball and keep quiet it was known that a lot of this money goes to building tunnels and buying weapons but not letting the money through without any substitute funding for the civil governance would be very problematic too i think the thing we can blame netanyahu for in this context is that he was comfortable with this ugly status quo which would somewhat predictably lead to a major attack instead of being serious about a peace process with the palestinians hamas is evil but in a diplomatic sense what it did was saying we re not willing to live like this for so long the occupation is bad and we need to end it of course the stated ideology of hamas is that there should be no israel but that doesn t mean that every ounce of support given to hamas would back this hawkish stance in isolation if the gazans were under the impression that a deal that gives them a state is imminent they would not support hamas so much or perhaps the hamas apparatus would become more dovish as for what bibi knew or didn t know i think it s kind of like the aftermath of you can point now at a million ways the cia fbi nsa could have busted the operation ahead of time but that doesn t mean anybody committed treason for one as it were hindsight is i e the fact it s obvious now doesn t mean it was obvious at the time second we may think that some of the indications should have been picked up on but that just means the relevant people in the government and security apparatus should have done a better job there were some indications on the night before and a few officers on the ground heeded it for example a navy officer that decided to dispatch extra patrol ships or something and probably prevented the death of a few dozen civilians on the shore but i bet similar indications were received pretty regularly in the months and years before the attack and most of the time they were false warnings']

eats from the fridge before killing them', 'why are children still being born in palestine i am not a native english speaker so i am using a translator i would appreciate a response in formal english i am not trying to criticize palestine i want to address this from a woman s perspective children are dying yet women continue to give birth are these births truly the result of women s free will how many women would want to keep giving birth while witnessing their children die in a war to what extent are women s rights protected within palestine i am afraid to raise this topic because it might be seen as siding with israel or suggesting that palestine is at fault however i am still curious is giving birth continuously a form of resistance against israel or are women living under pressure to keep having children despite the deaths of children in wartime isn t there any discussion about this add i expressed concern that raising this issue might lead to responses that demonize palestine making it difficult to speak out as expected such reactions have emerged this is hardly surprising please look at how i responded to those comments i absolutely do not agree with such views on the other hand there are also comments here that i find valuable and worth considering it is your choice what to believe add since i don t know how to pin a comment i ll just copy some comments by baker this is a good and fair question and i m assuming good faith despite some pretty strange undertones in the post so i ll do my best and assume it s worth answering with both empathy and facts women giving birth in gaza right now are shaped by overlapping realities of their cultural norms individual choice medical access and the pressures of life under siege some women do see continuing to have children as an act of resilience and continuity but for many it s also about long standing traditions religious beliefs and the fact that when people are really stressed out and having nothing to do they still have sex however i think the actual statistics may surprise you a bit the data i could find from the un on this shows the reality here is far from a story of unlimited choice i ll walk through some of it as it s pretty sobering fewer births unfpa reports that in the first half of there were births in gaza this is fewer than in the same period in with one in three pregnancies now high risk newborns are born fighting if they re born at all roughly of newborns are premature underweight or in need of neonatal intensive care and there s been a more than fold increase in stillbirths compared to three years ago high risk pregnancies have increased unicef estimates that around women in gaza each year have high risk pregnancies and about of births are preterm many of these outcomes are driven by malnutrition untreated medical conditions and the collapse of the health system of hospitals are gone only a handful of maternity hospitals are still functioning and last time i checked i believe who was reporting that more than of hospitals are damaged or destroyed nevermind the limited capacity of what remains marked increase in newborn deaths fuel and supply shortages have led to over newborn deaths simply because incubators or emergency care weren t available so the un agencies have been pretty explicit in the data that women children and newborns are disproportionately bearing the brunt of the conflict both as casualties and through the loss of even the most basic reproductive healthcare so while the reasons for having children are definitely personal and varied the conditions in which those births happen are now deeply constrained and brutal in sum yes tradition survival and resistance i am sure play some limited role but the human cost is staggering and reproductive rights in gaza right now exist in a context where the choice is heavily shaped by war not just by personal will edit putting some sources as requested unfpa situation report on the crisis in the occupied palestinian territory may june unicef palestine health and nutrition page doctors without borders how msf is responding to the war in gaza stats at bottom before see this can t find original comment']

Representative_Docs: ['hamas has every interest in inflating numbers and they say k and that likely includes deaths by natural causes i agree there s possibly more fog of war and all that but best but those who claim it are speculating based on an at least somewhat plausible set of assumptions finally the obvious which is that israel is clearly fighting a just war given october th it has the conduct in the war if ukraine had taken back all of their territory in a single day and then spent nine months bombing moscow and st petersburg into rubble while of the russian population was evacuated to siberia we wouldn t say that their conduct is beyond reproach because russia started it or because of bucha or because putin refuses to surrender we would rightly condemn any unnecessary killing or devastation imho the argument that israel is unduly targeting civilans just enough to have plausible deniability is pretty weak you could make that argument about any war and it s an journalists and of refusing neutral parties access to inspect prison facilities all of that combined it s not a stretch to speculate that israeli troops on the ground may well have committed genocide through random undisclosed and unjustified killings', 'notice that this number is the end figure and not the figures in the fog of war which are the numbers that we re seeing currently the point isn t Name: 64_trauma_death_justice_healing
Representative_Docs: ['if you feel this way and you kill someone you will be haunted for the rest of your life alternatively you will die or be mamed and dace disability for life if you don t go back out you will have to face prison which is isolating and an ugly experience but you will have a clear conscience for the rest of your life the experience will harden you either way i m sorry you are forced into this choice i hope you choose the later and seek therapy', 'no one s asking for your sympathy this isn t a pity contest victimhood might win headlines and weak make you look virtuous but it doesn t win wars if you can t protect your family you don t have the luxury of keeping one safe strength isn t something to apologize for power doesn t erase morality and it s not the same as cruelty if it were every cop would be a villain and that is real moralism because might defends the people close to you in the real world your moral standard seems to be weakness in exchange for sympathy what exactly are you suggesting that if you re not a loser you don t deserve to exist that s not morality that s naive and dangerously blind to how the world actually works', 'the only way to break a cycle of escalating violence is to stop escalating the violence even though the momentum of the cycle is pushing towards escalation and any specific escalation can be justified by its preceding event i am a therapist who has dedicated his career to working with trauma and i have seen these cycles of escalations writ small but still devastating in the lives of many individuals and families people who are hurt people who hurt others because they are hurting people who hurt others because they are afraid of being hurt themselves i hear the echos of pain and hurt throughout generations like ghosts that feed off of pain to grow stronger the first thing you learn in doing trauma work is that separating out victims and perpetrators is often a messy proposition and one that shifts depending on what time or what relationship you are focusing on in any given session people are often both sometimes even simultaneously if you go into trauma work looking to find heroes and villains you will find more than you ever thought possible and none at all the second thing you learn is that you cannot wait for the pain to lessen before the healing can begin the pain lessens because the healing begins the third thing you learn is that healing is not a passive experience it is often a courageous and defiant act against what the body and mind has learned is fundamentally necessary to keep themselves safe trauma tells truths about the dangers of the world but lies about the roads that travel from and through them it divides people relationships and experiences into rigid binaries of strength and weakness safety and vulnerability winners and losers fighters and victims trauma tells you that the only way to make it through the fire is to run faster fight harder and smash obstacles or set controlled burns ahead of you so the fire is always in your sight and never coming up from behind to heal means forgoing all that not listening to that damaged part of your psyche no matter how convinced it is that the fire is going to engulf you the moment you deviate from what it knows is the only way to keep you safe and fourth and perhaps most challenging at least for me lesson learned in trauma work is that true justice can be a lighthouse to steer one s ship but it isn t a destination many will ever reach that apology you hoped for may never be coming or may never fill the hole you hoped it would seeing your perpetrator suffer rarely makes your suffering feel any lighter hollywood endings are make believe but grace and forgiveness are real and accessible and their power towards healing often takes people by surprise so i will not answer your question as a diplomat or politician but i am not someone who hasn t sat at a table and helped negotiate functional treaties with trauma before it can be done in this case it would mean israel taking the bold and courageous step of choosing diplomacy and restraint over brute military force not because brute military force could not be justified but because it will ultimately further the cycle of trauma and escalation that is in no one s interest including israel s own israel could have seized the moment of initial international sympathy and shock to draw in closer to its western allies and the strained but with some recent progress towards normalizing relationships with the arab world itself and amplify international condemnation of hamas and unite pressure on and isolation of hamas amongst those who otherwise might have been less willing or engaged israel could have strengthened its relationship with fatah plo in the west bank through restarting meaningful negotiations there in return for real security guarantees and thereby showed the benefits of the alternative to the approach hamas took in gaza and israel could have negotiated prisoner exchanges for the hostages while also giving a clear deadline for further steps including militarily if the negotiations did not progress the negotiations would need time and undoubtedly gruelling patience and involvement from arab partners if they were to be fruitful but there may have been space for them to be successful under the right circumstances particularly if israel was able to use its restraint and its reopening of negotiations with fatah to build on its progress with normalizing its relationships in the arab world is this fair is this justice those are the wrong questions sadly if you are truly committed to healing and breaking free of the cycle of mutual destruction that is driving israelis and palestinians into the blood saturated ground a ground that doesn t care at all about fairness or justice as it swallows up generation and generation of people who were convinced that vengeance and might is the path to peace and security']

incendiary rhetoric deployed by israeli leaders middle east eye israelis no longer blush at calls for palestinian extermination middle east eye icj genocide case israeli rhetoric against palestinians central to south africa s case ap news', 'the nakba narrative is exaggerated and misleading this is a long one between per israel and per arab sources of the arabs exited between december and this means the number ranges between to arabs there are two main phases of the israeli war of independence or as the palestinians refer to it as the nakba phase one november through to mid may of the decision to partition the land to an arab and jewish state is adopted by the un in november of accepted by the jews and rejected by the arabs in this phase the british mandate is still in effect there is no israeli army formally there is the paramilitary organization of hagana which at the time is mostly focused on defending jewish towns and neighborhoods from arab attacks during this time at least to arabs leave and they do so on their own accord the reasons for their leaving range from not wanting to be part of the new jewish state if they stay according the un partition map and some out of fear from the impending full scale war that neighboring arab states were threatening if the jewish state were to be created these people were not expelled by israel in any shape or form the second phase from mid may through to the armistice signed in in this phase some arabs were expelled by israel some escaped because of the fear of war and some were advised to leave by arab countries and return with the victorious arab armies so during this period another to exit it is virtually impossible to tell what percent of these people left solely because they were expelled by the israeli army all evidence is that there was no formal policy of expulsion so even if were expelled by israel that would mean to people the claim one can make is that after the war ended they were not allowed back in but in all fairness their condition to coming back was the dismantling for the jewish state and also the jews that were expelled from arab countries were not let back in either the arab exodus began voluntarily as early as december when established arab families in haifa and jaffa realized that according to the un partition plan the cities they lived in were slated to fall under jewish control similarly wealthy arab residents from the western neighborhoods of jerusalem began to leave in historian benny morris s words the arab flight became a sort of contagious disease spreading from house to house neighbor to neighbor street to street neighborhood to neighborhood and later from village to village the upper and educated classes feared being killed or wounded and feared the anarchy that accompanied the gradual withdrawal of the british civil and military administration most of the high class families who left haifa jerusalem jaffa acre and tiberias believed their exile would be temporary this phenomenon was described in the contemporary palestinian press as follows the first group of the fifth column traitors are those abandoning their homes and businesses and going to live elsewhere many of them lived in great comfort and luxury as soon as the first sign of trouble appeared they took off to avoid bearing the burden of the struggle directly or indirectly the neighboring countries did us a great disservice by accepting these who fled the battlefield they are the worst type of our fifth column traitors and deserve the harshest punishment from the palestinian newspaper al sha ab june according to morris following their departure the peasants and urban poor were also forced to leave having witnessed the mass flight of the wealthy which led to the closure of businesses schools law offices clinics and public services adding to this was the withdrawal of the british the departing people left due to fear of being left to face the zionist enemy alone despite the poverty and difficulty associated with leaving morris describes the first months of for the arabs of palestine as follows feelings of general collapse and disintegration in many places a small spark was enough to make the residents pack up and flee residents of arab cities fled and in doing so dragged along with them the rural population of the surrounding areas the causes for the departure of roughly a quarter million arabs in the first half of were largely internal arab causes lack of leadership economic hardship breakdown of law and order the voluntary departure in the early months of the war due to the absence of leadership and collapse of order can be seen in this report from a palestinian newspaper the residents of the large village of sheikh munis and many other arab villages in the tel aviv area have disgraced us all by abandoning their villages with their belongings and their children one cannot avoid comparing this shameful flight with the steadfast stance of the haganah in settlements located in arab regions but what use are comparisons for we all know that the haganah rushes into battle with courage while we flee from war from the palestinian newspaper al siraj march the voluntary departure in spring due to calls from arab leaders and institutions is reflected in this report from the economist correspondent in palestine in the days that followed the israeli authorities who now had full control of haifa called upon all arabs to remain and assured them that no harm would come to them to the best of my knowledge all british residents who were asked by their arab friends advised them to stay various factors influenced their decision to flee there is little doubt that the strongest factor was the broadcasts from the arab higher committee which called on all arabs to leave haifa it was made clear to them that once british forces completed their evacuation the armies of all the arab states would invade palestine and drive the jews into the sea it was also implied that any arabs who remained in haifa and accepted jewish protection would be considered traitors at that time the arabs of palestine still had some trust in the arab league s ability to deliver on its promises from the economist london october about two years later the editor of the lebanese newspaper al huda habib issa summarized the matter in hindsight in an editorial immediately after the british publicly announced their departure from the mandate in palestine the arab league began convening meetings and conferences its secretary general abdul rahman azzam pasha issued many declarations promising the arab nations that conquering palestine and tel aviv effectively the jewish capital would be as simple as a military parade azzam s statements noted that the armies were already at the borders and that the millions of pounds spent by the jews on land acquisition and economic development would surely fall into arab hands since it would be a simple matter to throw the jews into the mediterranean the arabs of palestine had no choice but to listen to the advice of the league and believe what azzam pasha and others told them that leaving their lands was only temporary and would end within days with the successful completion of the arab campaign of punishment against israel from the daily lebanese newspaper al huda june expulsion orders formal organized expulsion orders were issued to palestinian arabs during the war on two main occasions during the implementation of plan dalet when the haganah shifted from defense to offense and expelled arabs from key transport routes and border areas after the conquest of ramla and lydda there is no dispute that some of the refugees were expelled but the actual number is likely less than of those who actually left the new historians with the opening of israeli and british archives years after the war a new wave of research emerged led by the so called new historians these scholars argued that everything previously published about the war was largely zionist propaganda by official historians however even they had to acknowledge many arabs left without being expelled their criticism of israel was that israeli policy was to prevent their return even when they wanted to return their return was banned villages destroyed fields ruined or handed over to jewish settlements etc both the british national library and national library of israel have physical copies of the papers containing the quotes provided above but could not find downloadable pdf versions']

cleansing is not genocide i am absolutely against ethnic cleansing of course and i oppose this policy completely what muddies the water on this topic though is the definition of ethnic cleansing unfortunately for many an almost inevitable outcome consider this if your sister were killed by an israeli missile with no apology acknowledgment or third party investigation despite her having no direct ties to any militant group resentment toward the israeli military and in some cases even toward israelis more broadly would be an understandable human response it is precisely this cycle of aggression dispossession and dehumanisation that compels many in gaza to join or support hamas not out of inherent hatred for jews bloodlust but rather out of desperation grief and the absence of alternatives and the same applies for relatives of victims of hamas attacks in israel what the world viewed as terrorism many palestinians saw as a desperate bid to secure a future for their children in extreme conditions rational thought often gives way to emotion and survival instincts while external observers may approach such events analytically those living under siege are driven by fear trauma and hopelessness moreover holding extremist or even offensive political views does not justify extrajudicial killing supporting a terrorist organization while morally wrong should not be conflated with actively participating in violence there s a vital distinction between endorsing agreeance with an ideology and engaging in criminal acts for instance although neo nazism is universally condemned modern moral and legal frameworks still reject the idea of executing individuals simply for holding such beliefs the same standard must apply here belief alone is not a death sentence as a side note i view that israel has placed itself in a morally irredeemable position where even if it were to achieve its desired goal of eradicating hamas the remaining underlying conditions would give rise to a similar political entity differing only in name the people of israel will likely continue to live in fear and danger in the near future and it seems that so will the people of palestine unfortunately to end on a more optimistic note we need to remember that all people regardless of their politics deserve a chance to live free from occupation oppression and uncertainty regardless of religion ethnicity nationality etc p s please do not comment asking me for condemnations regarding the attacks we all recognise that such attacks involved atrocious transgressions and i especially condemn any harm directed towards innocent people women and children during such attacks and have no intention of justifying or condoning the murder or abuse of any innocent human being p p s wording this argument was extremely difficult and you would likely find the tone choppy if you have any objections or things i said that you would like me to reiterate or expand on please let me know']

Name: 277_geneva_geneva convention_convention_the geneva
Representative_Docs: ['i think you might be slightly over interpreting what the th geneva convention says in sections on must apply military law article says the starting point is that the existing laws of the occupied territory remain in force the occupying power can amend or suspend them if they pose a security threat or block the application of the convention that can involve military orders but it doesn t require blanket application of military law to the entire occupied population on must be a military court article allows the use of military courts for breaches of penal provisions created under occupation it says that if they are used they must be non political and based in the occupied territory that s permission not an obligation local courts can still operate for most matters on separate prisons article says detainees should be held in the occupied territory and separated from other categories of detainees it s about proximity and humane treatment not building an entirely separate prison network for the occupied population on different laws the laws must be different claim flips the text on its head the convention s baseline is legal continuity you only change the laws when security needs make it necessary the th geneva convention was designed for temporary occupations with minimal disruption to local law and society it s not a blank cheque for decades long systemic legal separation between two populations living in the same territory', 'geneva convention iv article of the geneva convention iv provides each high contracting party shall allow the free passage of all consignments of medical and hospital stores intended only for civilians of another high contracting party even if the latter is its adversary it shall likewise permit the free passage of all consignments of essential foodstuffs clothing and tonics intended for children under fifteen expectant mothers and maternity cases the obligation of a high contracting party to allow the free passage of the consignments indicated in the previous paragraph is subject to the condition that this party is satisfied that there are no serious reasons for fearing a that the consignments may be diverted from their destination b that the control may not be effective or c that a definite advantage may accrue to the military efforts or economy of the enemy through the substitution of the above mentioned consignments for goods which would otherwise be provided or produced by the enemy or through the release of such material services or facilities as would otherwise be required for the production of such goods the power which allows the passage of the consignments indicated in the first paragraph of this article may make such permission conditional on the distribution to the persons benefited thereby being made under the local supervision of the protecting powers sorry but it s you who haven t read about internacional law under international law israel has no obligation to provide aid i ve read the law but it wouldn t surprise me if this is the first time you ve ever seen this', 'the geneva convention']

Name: 296_marriage_gay_married_couples
Representative_Docs: ['since when have these threads become a place for asinine redditors to come and flamboyantly display their ignorance israel is one of most gay friendly countries in the world tel aviv is considered by some as the lgbtq capital of the world the rabanoot does not grant religious marriage certificates to same sex couples but there are multiple other methods that they can receive civil marriage certificates within israel they are officialy recognized as married and get all the benefits by government authorities claiming that gay marriage is illegal in israel is just a blatant lie and manipulation of the truth', 'yes you can get gay married inside israel the process is a bit lol though but you can previously you could only get married inside the country in different courts that were all religious in nature those religious courts were all either jewish muslim christian and druze since all these religions are against gay marriage you couldn t get gay married in israel however israel recognized marriages done in courts overseas too so you could gay married overseas and it would be recognized in israel however beginning in israel started recognizing marriages done by courts overseas performed online so you can get gay married in israel certified by an overseas court while you re still in israel basically just get gay married in israel with a foreign marriage court or minister watching on zoom and congratulations you re husband and husband or wife and wife', 'this is a bit misleading israel doesn t have civil marriage just like many muslim countries don t but it does legally recognize any marriage performed abroad including the new utah zoom option that emerged during covid so there s no gay marriage performed locally only because none of the religious bodies authorized to perform marriages the orthodox rabbinate the sharia courts and the churches happen to perform gay marriage if for instance the rabbinate changed its mind on same sex marriage it would be instantly legal for jews in israel the sharia system in israel does allow muslim men to marry non muslim women in a muslim wedding ceremony so that s legal the rabbinate won t perform intermarriage and neither will druze imams but i m not sure about the christian churches israel does however have a domestic partnership status that s open to both hetero and same sex couples as well as mixed faith couples which has many of the same rights and benefits as marriage so many gay couples will do that and do a legal wedding ceremony next time they re able to take a trip abroad the lack of a local legal option for same sex marriage is certainly an issue and it s something people advocate for but it s not something that the local lgbtq community considers to be terribly oppressive due to the above mentioned loopholes and alternatives available and gay couples are still able to adopt children and use surrogates']

since we ve been discussing the israeli palestinian conflict on the sub i would like to ask your opinions on what it means to be indigenous academically there isn t an agreed upon definition of what it means to be indigenous for some people it s about who was there first for others it s blood quantum additionally it s about those who ve maintained a continued presence in a land and its relationship to it after conducting extensive research on both jews and palestinians i have come to the conclusion that both groups are indigenous to the land in different ways the palestinians are descendants of the original canaanite and levantine peoples many of whom are also descendants of jews jewish christians and samaritans particularly those in nablus over the years palestinians experienced significant cultural shifts due to being under the rule of the rashidun caliphate which was led by the companions of the prophet muhammad abu bakr umar ibn al khattab khalid ibn al walid and abu ubaidah ibn al jarrah over time the palestinians in the region gradually moved away from speaking aramaic and greek instead adopting arabic as their primary language alongside this shift there was a gradual conversion to islam for those who chose not to convert paying the jizya tax was required to support the various needs of the caliphate while modern day jews are an ethnoreligious group that can trace their origins to judea palestine who would migrate out of the region as a result of the various militaristic conflicts that were present at the time most notably the roman empire these jewish migrants would later travel across europe north africa and the middle east and would intermarry with the local women who would convert to judaism from the populations they migrated to and thus creating the various sub ethnicities within the jewish ethnoreligious framework ashkenazim sephardim mizrahim despite the fact that the vast majority of jews have lived outside the region for years they have maintained a connection to their ancestral roots this has been achieved by preserving their religion using hebrew and aramaic for religious purposes marrying exclusively within the jewish community to uphold their identity and most notably by reciting the phrase l shana haba ah b yerushalayim next year in jerusalem at the end of every passover seder which expresses their hope to return indigenous to palestine eretz israel because their ancestors were displaced from the land thousands of years ago neglects the shared heritage and diverse descent of many other groups over billion people worldwide have spiritual and cultural descent from the ancient israelites through abrahamic faiths like christianity islam and bah i indigeneity involves more than just being the first people to inhabit a land it encompasses factors such as land stewardship continuous habitation cultural distinctiveness and recent dispossession by settler colonialism palestinians and other groups have continuously inhabited and stewarded the land for centuries maintaining distinct cultural practices and identities connected to ancient peoples of the region when europeans colonized the lands of the iroquois confederacy and algonquian tribes all native inhabitants became designated as indigenous despite their own internal conflicts over land and resources similarly liberia s establishment by african american settlers illustrates that having ancestral ties to a region does not automatically confer indigeneity these settlers were not indigenous to liberia despite their ancestry heritage and current indigeneity are distinct concepts while cultural and spiritual affinity with a group s ancient past is significant the moral political and legal status of being indigenous to a region is tied to recent and ongoing historical contexts of displacement and dispossession not distant ancient history zionism is not some land back movement that seeks to return land and sovereignty to indigenous Name: 398_bias_yatta_bias when_masafer
Representation: ['bias', 'yatta', 'bias when', 'masafer', 'palestinian propaganda', 'masafer yatta', 'film', 'average reader', 'overall understanding', 'objectively accurate']
Representative_Docs: ['yes there s a whole online ecosystem of extremely sensationalized and biased pro palestinian media it starts with al jazeera and less reputable propaganda websites like middle east eye mondoweiss electronic intifada etc the stories get filtered through twitter tiktok youtube and twitch and reposted on subreddits whose mod teams are hijacked by activists there s a similar hijacking happening on wikipedia the result is a massive firehose of propaganda for all the talk about israel s hasbara efforts they re quite pathetic compared to the coordination on the other side', 'bias lies for the most part typically we see three main forms of bias coverage bias when media choose to report only negative news about one party or ideology gatekeeping bias also known as selectivity or selection bias when stories are selected or deselected sometimes on ideological grounds it is sometimes also referred to as agenda bias when the focus is on political actors and whether they are covered based on their preferred policy issues statement bias also known as tonality bias or presentation bias when media coverage is slanted towards or against particular actors or issues israeli sources will absolutely be biased meaning they will likely only post that which benefits them or discredits the enemy but this does not mean you should immediately disregard what they say especially if picture or video evidence is provided the same with palestinian sources due to the nature of the conflict we will for the most part only see primary evidence from israeli s and palestinians and so this is the best we can get currently in terms of an overall understanding of what is happening take things with a pinch of salt sure but to flat out disregard evidence from either side is often a product of our own bias which is hypocritical', 'expressions such as x was trivial to find mean that the act of finding x was very simple obvious it has no relation to the claim that the content of x is trivial your second paragraph is in general confused and incorrect reporting on any set of known facts can almost always be accomplished through multiple different titles and descriptions that are all objectively accurate but differ in the narrative they emphasize and the overall understanding they provide to the average reader reporters understand this and choose their words and their placement accordingly reporting on a military operation with the title of palestinian teen shot in israeli raid immediately followed by israeli troops shot and killed a palestinian teenage boy is one particular such choice out of many objectively accurate ways to convey the available information and one that promotes a particular interpretation of the situation which given prior history of such cases has a high probability of being incorrect journalists and editors normally understand perfectly well how the average reader will read and understand those words what existing tropes and narratives it leverages and reinforces and what conclusions readers are likely to draw as a result i agree that this can be the result of incompetence or an innocent sort of bias and not necessarily an intent to deceive or knowingly reinforce palestinian propaganda which speaking of strawmen is a claim that neither op nor i have made but deceiving and reinforcing palestinian propaganda is what such reporting achieves in practice']

than speak ill of those who they support or well of those they oppose if they say anything at all it s muted and less frequent i don t think this will surprise anyone and the mute critics needn t be
